title: It is legal to sing the happy birthday song in public? - Quora
tags: Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life

response.answer_text: It was never “illegal” to sing happy birthday in public. Let’s put that out there. Prior to 2016, you could have sung “Happy Birthday To You” in public until you were blue in the face, as long as you paid Warner/Chappelle (a unit that once belonged to Warner Bros and now a unit of Warner Music Group) US$700 in a licensing fee per performance. This prompted many restaurants and public facilities to bypass that old song and write their own jaunty birthday tune. After a three-year trial, the Supreme Court declared “Happy Birthday To You” is in the public domain, meaning no one has control over the song nor will collect any royalties from it. So sing it until you turn blue in the face.

Ok, here’s the deal. Sing whatever you like anywhere you want. It’s legal. What you can’t do is sing a copyrighted song for money without paying the royalty. So, if you own a restaurant and you pay your staff to sing a song on a patron’s birthday, then because money exchanges hands for this service as part of their job, they can’t sing anything under copyright protection without paying the royalties. I believe the claim to the birthday song was also recently voided, so go ahead and sing it. Just please don’t sing it at my table.
